componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Nik Modi from UBS.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Marty, can you just comment on the share again -- I mean there was significant this quarter. Just wondering aside from wonderful management, what exactly is driving this magnitude of share gains? Was there something going on in the competitive landscape?
componenttext: Marty, can you just comment on the share again -- I mean there was significant this quarter. Just wondering aside from wonderful management, what exactly is driving this magnitude of share gains? Was there something going on in the competitive landscape?  And then the other question is can you give us a sense on how much potential inventory you believe is kind of excess in the channel so we can better understand kind of what the trend could look like in the second quarter?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the share gains, well, it is very good management. And I might add, our share gains are solely due to organic growth. They're not a by-product of line extending and filling pipelines with the new versions of Newport. I think it's a continuatio
componenttext: In terms of the share gains, well, it is very good management. And I might add, our share gains are solely due to organic growth. They're not a by-product of line extending and filling pipelines with the new versions of Newport. I think it's a continuation of our strategy, as we said in our release and I think I said in my own comments, the execution of our strategy, which is to be very targeted with respect to where we support the Newport brand and market by market and conceivably, certain decisions made by our competitors that are helping us as opposed to helping themselves. But beyond that, nothing's changed for us. We've consistently executed our target-marketed approach to investment spending, and by that, I mean promotion support for Newport in select markets based on their potential for profitable return of share growth. And that's -- obviously, it continues to work well for us. With respect to the excess inventory in the system, we estimate that it's about 200 million units, mostly Newport that are in the system that are likely to be flushed out, as I indicated, sometime in the second quarter. It's hard to say when. We don't know specifically what the motivation of the purchases, behind the purchases were, but if it was related to price, then somebody's holding on until there might be a price increase. But we don't know that for a fact.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And just on the Newport front, in terms of what was shipped from wholesale to retail. Would it kind of like a 3% to 4% down numbers make sense for the quarter?
componenttext: And just on the Newport front, in terms of what was shipped from wholesale to retail. Would it kind of like a 3% to 4% down numbers make sense for the quarter?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: You mean in the first quarter?
componenttext: You mean in the first quarter?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: No. Adjusted, we're about flat.
componenttext: No. Adjusted, we're about flat.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Adelman from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Adelman from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Marty, I want to understand about the extra units that built up during the quarter. Does this quarter's income statement reflect the promotional costs that will ultimately be associated with the retail sell-through of that product?
componenttext: Marty, I want to understand about the extra units that built up during the quarter. Does this quarter's income statement reflect the promotional costs that will ultimately be associated with the retail sell-through of that product?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: No. Let me point out something else, David. This buildup didn't just begin in the first quarter of this year. So it was -- it began in the fourth quarter of last year and carried through. So it's not a -- it wasn't a sudden effect or impact, and so these
componenttext: No. Let me point out something else, David. This buildup didn't just begin in the first quarter of this year. So it was -- it began in the fourth quarter of last year and carried through. So it's not a -- it wasn't a sudden effect or impact, and so these units do not carry any costs beyond what we've got by selling the units.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So to be clear, let's imagine if some of it comes out next quarter, you'll both not have those shipments, but also you'll have promotional expense associated with the sell-through of that volume.
componenttext: So to be clear, let's imagine if some of it comes out next quarter, you'll both not have those shipments, but also you'll have promotional expense associated with the sell-through of that volume.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure I understand. What do you mean by promotional [ph]?
componenttext: I'm not sure I understand. What do you mean by promotional [ph]?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: In other words, with these units that sold -- as the unit do build up in the inventory, are they particularly profitable volume, because you don't have the associated promotional spending costs?
componenttext: In other words, with these units that sold -- as the unit do build up in the inventory, are they particularly profitable volume, because you don't have the associated promotional spending costs?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. They're pure profit but we don't lose anything. The promotional costs associated with retail promotion spending only is effective when the unit is in the store and moves out. It has nothing to do, there's no relationship, no correlation to promotiona
componenttext: Yes. They're pure profit but we don't lose anything. The promotional costs associated with retail promotion spending only is effective when the unit is in the store and moves out. It has nothing to do, there's no relationship, no correlation to promotional expense at all.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I realize it's early days in the process, but as it relates to the FDA and the menthol study, is there anything that's occurred so far that causes you to alter in any way your assessment of the likely ultimate outcome of the process?
componenttext: I realize it's early days in the process, but as it relates to the FDA and the menthol study, is there anything that's occurred so far that causes you to alter in any way your assessment of the likely ultimate outcome of the process?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: No, the initial meetings in our minds were not surprising in any real sense. We certainly expected the thrust of the meetings to be as they were. So nothing's really materially changed in our minds, even though obviously there was a burst of interest and
componenttext: No, the initial meetings in our minds were not surprising in any real sense. We certainly expected the thrust of the meetings to be as they were. So nothing's really materially changed in our minds, even though obviously there was a burst of interest and noise surrounding the meetings but nothing's changed as far as we're concerned. The issue remains the same. It doesn't make any difference what any posturing might take place during the course of these meetings. And any speculation that might grow out of that posturing, the reality is as we've said repeatedly, the weight of the evidence from an demonological standpoint and other aspects of studies that have been conducted would not reflect that menthol is any different in terms of its effect on the public health than non-menthol cigarettes are. That isn't changed... We also believe that the FDA will be obligated to review the contraband dimension, associated with potential -- if in fact there was any thought about banning menthol cigarettes, what that might imply. None of that's changed.  So we have not altered our view either.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: As it relates to Maverick, is that brand benefiting from increases in its distribution? Or is the growth simply selling more within the existing store footprint?
componenttext: As it relates to Maverick, is that brand benefiting from increases in its distribution? Or is the growth simply selling more within the existing store footprint?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say at this point, it's mostly benefiting from organic growth where it is. Obviously, it continues to gain distribution but most of the gains from distribution occurred probably about a year ago. Right now, we're just -- it's pure it's incremental
componenttext: I would say at this point, it's mostly benefiting from organic growth where it is. Obviously, it continues to gain distribution but most of the gains from distribution occurred probably about a year ago. Right now, we're just -- it's pure it's incremental growth.

componenttext: Lastly on the emotional [indiscernible] tobacco efforts, do you have anything as of yet in test?

componenttext: No, we have not. And we'll let you know when we do.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Judy Hong from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Judy Hong from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Marty, I know that there's a lot of noise in the quarter for the industry as a whole and for your perspective, but just getting a broad sense of where the industry really stands right now, obviously, it's been a year since you had the excise tax increases
componenttext: Marty, I know that there's a lot of noise in the quarter for the industry as a whole and for your perspective, but just getting a broad sense of where the industry really stands right now, obviously, it's been a year since you had the excise tax increases, it seems like the premium segment's starting to stabilize. Can you just give us your broad assessment of where you think the industry is in both on the volume side and just in terms of the promotional environment.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the promotional I think go from the back-end to the front. The promotional environment has not changed radically. It's been pretty much consistent frankly, for the last year or so. So there's really nothing of any major consequence promotionally tha
componenttext: Well, the promotional I think go from the back-end to the front. The promotional environment has not changed radically. It's been pretty much consistent frankly, for the last year or so. So there's really nothing of any major consequence promotionally that's affecting the business. To be honest with you, Judy, it's very difficult to reach a conclusion as I think I've indicated, with respect to where the trends are, with respect to the industry itself. I think each company has its own unique set of issues. Each major company has its unique set of issues that make it difficult at this stage of the game to sort of step back and look at it and say here's kind of where it's heading. I still think that we're going to be slightly worse than the industry. We'll be slightly worse than historical trends, with respect to overall shipment decline for 2010 versus 2009, with the magic percentages, I don't know. I've said somewhere in the range of 4% to 5%. I don't know how accurate that is. It's still very difficult to surmise what is actually going to happen out there. We had some noise in the first quarter from a volume standpoint, not only because of the upward adjusted on the wholesale inventories side, but because one of our major competitors introduced a line extension and had a huge impact, unit volume wise, on the industry numbers obviously. It inflated the [indiscernible]. So it's real tough at this stage of the game to determine where it's going to come out.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: But it seems like if we sort of take a lot of the numbers that you've given us as it relates to inventory movement, there may be a few adjusted Newport kind of being flat-ish on an underlying level, where the industry in the first quarter is still negativ
componenttext: But it seems like if we sort of take a lot of the numbers that you've given us as it relates to inventory movement, there may be a few adjusted Newport kind of being flat-ish on an underlying level, where the industry in the first quarter is still negatively impacted by year-over-year pricing. It just seems like the Newport's, either the gap between Newport versus the industry is widening or maybe the industry is starting to look more normal?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know what normal is, Judy. We may have a redefinition of normal and that's my point. I don't know and I think each -- if we look at our retail numbers in the first quarter, then I would say we were growing stronger week-to-week as we've moved thro
componenttext: I don't know what normal is, Judy. We may have a redefinition of normal and that's my point. I don't know and I think each -- if we look at our retail numbers in the first quarter, then I would say we were growing stronger week-to-week as we've moved through the quarter on a comparative basis, with the first quarter of last year. But the first quarter of last year as you well know, is a very, very distorted picture. So I'm not going to comment any further. It would be purely speculation on my part and I really don't have an answer to your question. I think we're going to have to wait and see as the old cliché goes, time heals all wounds and will tell us what the trends are.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: David, on the settlement accruals, you said there was favorability in the quarter on some adjustments, can you quantify how much that was and is that just the first quarter issue or still the favorability throughout the year?
componenttext: David, on the settlement accruals, you said there was favorability in the quarter on some adjustments, can you quantify how much that was and is that just the first quarter issue or still the favorability throughout the year?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: There were some favorable adjustments in the first quarter when we got final assessment on both the four states and the MSA numbers when the builds finally came in,had to do with volume adjustment offset, volume adjustment. I would guess that on MSA per p
componenttext: There were some favorable adjustments in the first quarter when we got final assessment on both the four states and the MSA numbers when the builds finally came in,had to do with volume adjustment offset, volume adjustment. I would guess that on MSA per pack level Judy, it impacted us between 3% in 4% favorably.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: 3% to 4% on a per unit basis?
componenttext: 3% to 4% on a per unit basis?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Growe with Stifel Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Growe with Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to ask you, Marty on promotional spending in the quarter, would that have been like on a dollar basis, would have been -- it sounds like was no change may be in rate of spending, would it have been down in the quarter though?
componenttext: I just want to ask you, Marty on promotional spending in the quarter, would that have been like on a dollar basis, would have been -- it sounds like was no change may be in rate of spending, would it have been down in the quarter though?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It's down slightly, yes.
componenttext: It's down slightly, yes.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Is there a LIFO charge this quarter that -- as we've seen in the past few quarters?
componenttext: Is there a LIFO charge this quarter that -- as we've seen in the past few quarters?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: That's a tough question. We've added our inventory in a LIFO method, yes, and so there will be, we estimate a LIFO charge during 2010. As you know, it's an annual calculation so all we can do is make some estimates. Yes, there will be an expected LIFO cha
componenttext: That's a tough question. We've added our inventory in a LIFO method, yes, and so there will be, we estimate a LIFO charge during 2010. As you know, it's an annual calculation so all we can do is make some estimates. Yes, there will be an expected LIFO charge during the year, but we also expect it to be substantially less than last year.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: A broad question for you Marty, relative to price gaps in the category today, if you look at them and we've seen them come down for some of the other premium brands, kind of that low 30% range, is that the right level? As we've seen the consumer pick up f
componenttext: A broad question for you Marty, relative to price gaps in the category today, if you look at them and we've seen them come down for some of the other premium brands, kind of that low 30% range, is that the right level? As we've seen the consumer pick up from here, should we see that expand a bit as you or other economists attempt to kind of better balance profitability against market share growth. Do you see that as an opportunity for the premium brands throughout the year?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: The price gap has become almost an aberrational factor in a way. Keep in mind, I know you're aware of this, when the S&T increase took place the price gaps automatically narrowed between high and low just because the basis of low-priced brands and high-pr
componenttext: The price gap has become almost an aberrational factor in a way. Keep in mind, I know you're aware of this, when the S&T increase took place the price gaps automatically narrowed between high and low just because the basis of low-priced brands and high-priced brands were different and with a mathematical effect or average medical. So then with state excise taxes going up and they have, and will continue to, it affects the GAAP. So to some extent, we're captives other than anyone taking a very specific action to get a lower rate in prices. So it's a hard one to answer. I don't know. I think it's what it is and we don't manage to price gaps per se, not between high and low. We manage our pricing to ensure that we're competitive, but we don't really look at price gaps. We look at it as a piece of information.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess for your brand, for the Newport Brand, you're not managing to that but in the sense, the competition in your category remains high so arguably that, however you look at it, but the price gap couldn't really expand any in the short run given ho
componenttext: And I guess for your brand, for the Newport Brand, you're not managing to that but in the sense, the competition in your category remains high so arguably that, however you look at it, but the price gap couldn't really expand any in the short run given how competitive the activity is in the category, is that the right way to say if?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Are you saying the price gaps could expand?
componenttext: Are you saying the price gaps could expand?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm saying could not based on your view of the competitive conditions in your category, they remain high, right?
componenttext: I'm saying could not based on your view of the competitive conditions in your category, they remain high, right?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's a hard question to answer. I don't know whether they -- if you're saying 30% is low and we can go higher, I don't think that's the issue per se. And I really can't answer for what anyone else would do.
componenttext: Yes. It's a hard question to answer. I don't know whether they -- if you're saying 30% is low and we can go higher, I don't think that's the issue per se. And I really can't answer for what anyone else would do.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Andrew Kieley from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Andrew Kieley from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Marty, I was going back to the FDA compliance committee, I was wondering if you could talk about how Lorillard might approach the data request that the committee's made, does some of that data they're looking for even exist and how you think about that?
componenttext: Marty, I was going back to the FDA compliance committee, I was wondering if you could talk about how Lorillard might approach the data request that the committee's made, does some of that data they're looking for even exist and how you think about that?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: We will comply with the request to the best of our ability. If the information is there they'll receive it, if it isn't then obviously, we won't be able to provide them with that -- whatever that might be. It's not an issue per se. We're obviously, this i
componenttext: We will comply with the request to the best of our ability. If the information is there they'll receive it, if it isn't then obviously, we won't be able to provide them with that -- whatever that might be. It's not an issue per se. We're obviously, this is -- requests for information of the tobacco company is not anything new to us. There are zillions of documents sitting in Minnesota someplace. So we will comply as we are obligated to.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So it seems like a lot of the documentation or data has already been disclosed previously by the industry?
componenttext: So it seems like a lot of the documentation or data has already been disclosed previously by the industry?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It depends on what it is. If it's product specific, then FDA may be asking for data that may not have been divulged or provided in previous discovery requests. It's just there, but I wouldn't make any distinction about this. The data is the data. We have
componenttext: It depends on what it is. If it's product specific, then FDA may be asking for data that may not have been divulged or provided in previous discovery requests. It's just there, but I wouldn't make any distinction about this. The data is the data. We have it, we'll provide it. There's really nothing to examine relative to that question.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Secondly, just on Maverick, can you give us a number on growth of distribution points or maybe where distribution is relative to Newport now?
componenttext: Secondly, just on Maverick, can you give us a number on growth of distribution points or maybe where distribution is relative to Newport now?

componenttextpreview: Maverick is pretty much following a similar pattern to Newport distribution but it's across the country. We have -- and in some retail outlets, Maverick may have a distribution method slightly different than Newport. There's no real specific pattern of di
componenttext: Maverick is pretty much following a similar pattern to Newport distribution but it's across the country. We have -- and in some retail outlets, Maverick may have a distribution method slightly different than Newport. There's no real specific pattern of difference or one way or the other there.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Just for David, could you tell us how much is total dollar amount is in the dispute accounts for the MSA now? Where are you in arbitrations for that or is there a process going on right now?
componenttext: Just for David, could you tell us how much is total dollar amount is in the dispute accounts for the MSA now? Where are you in arbitrations for that or is there a process going on right now?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Arbitration process is going on, but it goes on in fits and starts and there's been many hurdles and twists and turns to the process. We don't know when it's going to really begin in earnest, it will be quite some months, I'm sure. The aggregate amount th
componenttext: Arbitration process is going on, but it goes on in fits and starts and there's been many hurdles and twists and turns to the process. We don't know when it's going to really begin in earnest, it will be quite some months, I'm sure. The aggregate amount that's in the disputed account for Lorillard. I don't have it the tip of my fingers, but you can put it together with all the previous disclosures that we put in the 10-K and we just deposited $92 million more into that disputed account in April.

componenttext: I don't really recall what it is. I don't have it but it's pretty substantial, whatever it is.

componenttext: Nothing to read into this, Thilo. I believe you did in the Report you issued a couple of weeks ago. It is nothing more than our assuming of function that we didn't have in the first place as we moved as an independent publicly traded company. It was a logical step in fulfilling our capability to maintain relationships with people, on the investors and analysts. And there's nothing more to it than that.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: You do have a follow-up question from David Adelman of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: You do have a follow-up question from David Adelman of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Marty, a question for you as the mid-year this year lights and medium terminology is going to be removed, and the question is do you think there's sufficient distinction on the packaging of the various Newport brands for consumers to clearly identify and
componenttext: Marty, a question for you as the mid-year this year lights and medium terminology is going to be removed, and the question is do you think there's sufficient distinction on the packaging of the various Newport brands for consumers to clearly identify and call out their preferred products. Or do you think you need to institute on some of the smaller SKUs, some differentiated graphics to what you currently have?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're fine. We did a thorough review of this a year ago and made certain modification to the graphics to ensure that they were differentiated graphic mentioned to the packaging. So we're not concerned about it. We think we've accomplished what we
componenttext: I think we're fine. We did a thorough review of this a year ago and made certain modification to the graphics to ensure that they were differentiated graphic mentioned to the packaging. So we're not concerned about it. We think we've accomplished what we needed to.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Carolyn Mark from Federated Investors.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Carolyn Mark from Federated Investors.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me clarify something. Newport is in national distribution. Newport is in probably at least 200,000 to 300,000 outlets, maybe more, maybe 500,000. Whatever number of stores out there that sell cigarettes, Newport is pretty well represented. So Newport
componenttext: Let me clarify something. Newport is in national distribution. Newport is in probably at least 200,000 to 300,000 outlets, maybe more, maybe 500,000. Whatever number of stores out there that sell cigarettes, Newport is pretty well represented. So Newport is nationally distributed. When we make distinctions about Newport's business development, on a geographic basis, from a development standpoint, and by that, I mean in terms of its market share achieved, it varies by geography. And yet the Northeast and the Southeast tend to have above average sales or of market share than Newport then does the West. But we do sell cigarettes in the West. We're not non-existent in any of those locations. Maverick again is in national distribution. It's always been in national distribution and when we've added distribution, we added more packings or SKUs as the brand has grown, but both Newport and Maverick, I can't emphasize enough, is in national distribution.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: No. Not all.
componenttext: No. Not all.

componenttext: No. The existence of the number and the word deficit does not preclude us from doing any of those corporate actions.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Lorillard Inc. First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Alicia and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Bob Bannon, Dire
componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Lorillard Inc. First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Alicia and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Bob Bannon, Director Investor Relations at Lorillard. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alicia and good morning, everyone. I'm Bob Bannon, Lorillard's new Director of Investor Relations and joining me on today's call is Marty Orlowsky, Lorillard's Chairman, President, and Chief Executive Officer; and David Taylor, is Chief Financi
componenttext:
Thank you, Alicia and good morning, everyone. I'm Bob Bannon, Lorillard's new Director of Investor Relations and joining me on today's call is Marty Orlowsky, Lorillard's Chairman, President, and Chief Executive Officer; and David Taylor, is Chief Financial Officer. By now, you should have received a copy of our first quarter of 2010 earnings release. It can be found on the company's website, www.lorillard.com under News Releases.
But before we begin, I'd like to remind you that some of the comments on today's call and some of the responses to your questions may contain forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to the risks and uncertainties as described in the company's earnings release and in other filings with the SEC. I'd now like to turn the call over to Marty Orlowsky.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Good morning, everyone. Lorillard's very positive first quarter 2010, results fundamentally reflect consistent execution of our business strategy and the underlying strength of our flagship brand, Newport.As many of you are aware, there's a
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Good morning, everyone. Lorillard's very positive first quarter 2010, results fundamentally reflect consistent execution of our business strategy and the underlying strength of our flagship brand, Newport.
As many of you are aware, there's a degree of noise surrounding the cigarette industry and individual company unit shipment patterns, comparing quarter-over-quarter performance. When gauging Lorillard's relative performance within the industry in terms of market and segment shares and operating profit per thousand cigarettes shipped, it is clear that Lorillard continues to achieve a solid balance between profitability and market pledge share results.
I'm not going to get into too much detail regarding the reasons for the wholesale inventory differences between the first quarters of 2010 and 2009, other than to acknowledge that Lorillard was affected by the upward adjustment of wholesale inventories during the first quarter of 2010, and that tended to distort our wholesale shipment comparisons with the first quarter of 2009 in a manner not dissimilar to some of our competitors.
Additionally, certain of our wholesale customers increased their purchases at levels above what we believe the demand trends would imply. Consequently, it is believed that some of this excess inventory in the pipeline will be flushed out in the not-too-distant future. We would further anticipate that the second quarter of 2010 will have its own unique set of variables affecting comparisons between that quarter and the second quarter of 2009. As such, we would suggest that any observations regarding industry and company trends for 2010 as compared with the prior year be deferred until a full six months worth of data is available for 2010 and then compare with the first six months of 2009.
Let me then focus on unit volume numbers and rate of change that's subject to any number of distortion. We think it more constructive to briefly review share of market data that is more indicative of relative market performance. And during the first quarter of 2010, Lorillard achieved its highest retail share of 12.61%, an overall increase of 1.17 market share points, led by Newport, 10.9% share of market, a gain of 0.75 points; and Maverick's 1.37% share of the retail market, an increase of 0.44 points when compared with the first quarter of 2009. Newport gained 1.21 menthol segment share points in the first quarter of '10 over the first quarter of 2009, reaching a share of 36 points, almost 5% of the menthol segment for the quarter.
Viewing our retail data, sequentially, between the fourth quarter of '09 and the first quarter of '10, a positive pattern emerges. Lorillard increased its domestic retail share by 0.67 points, and Newport was up 0.58 points. Lorillard was the only major company to increase or hold steady both its retail share and rate of volume change between the fourth and the first quarters just mentioned. Lorillard's operating income per 1,000 units shipped achieved for the first quarter of 2010 was $43.10 per 1,000 versus Philip Morris USA, $36.87, and RJR's $27.06.
These results reflect percent increases over the first quarter of '09 of 16.1%, 7.5% and 6.7%, respectively to each company. While we're very pleased with our results for the first quarter of this year, as they do reflect solid fundamentals for the business, we obviously have to look at the first quarter of last year and the second quarter of '09 that were greatly affected by events leading up to an out of the timing for the April federal excise tax increase, creating a very difficult basis for comparing year-over-year results. However, we do feel that we are well positioned to effectively compete in this environment and continue our strategy of balancing Newport's market share performance and optimizing profitability. And now I'll turn the discussion over to David Taylor who will review our financials for you.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning. I'll spend the next few minutes talking about the numbers, and then we'll open the line for questions. Net sales for the first quarter of 2010 were $1.36 billion compared to $917 million for the first quarter of 2009. Excluding
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning. I'll spend the next few minutes talking about the numbers, and then we'll open the line for questions. Net sales for the first quarter of 2010 were $1.36 billion compared to $917 million for the first quarter of 2009. Excluding excise taxes, net sales increased by $156 million or 20.3% from $767 million to $923 million. Total wholesale shipments increased 12.1% compared to last year's first quarter. Higher average selling prices and lower sales promotion costs accounted for as a  reduction of net sales also contributed to the increase in net sales.
Of course, as Marty pointed out, simple comparisons to last year can be misleading. This year, not only did we not see the kind of tax-driven inventory reduction that occurred in last year's first quarter, we saw wholesale inventories build during the quarter, further skewing reasonable comparisons. As we look into our upcoming second quarter, the impact of the wholesale inventory rebuild in last year's second quarter will obviously negatively impact volume comparisons. And if the wholesale inventory increase that occurred in this year's first quarter that was mentioned just a moment ago reverses itself, as Marty mentioned, this comparability issue will be even more dramatic.
Gross profit in the first quarter of 2010 increased by $95 million to $478 million or 51.8% of sales excluding excise taxes, from $383 million or 49.9% of sales excluding excise taxes in the first quarter last year. Cost of goods sold in the first quarter of 2010 as compared to the first quarter of 2009 reflect increases for certain raw material costs, such as tobacco and wrapping costs and a new FDA fee.
Amounts due under the State Settlement Agreements increased $29 million compared to last year's first quarter as a result of a unit volume increase and the inflation factors in those agreements. Both increases were partially offset by certain other favorable adjustments in the quarter.
Selling, general and administrative costs increased $7 million to $96 million in the first quarter of 2010 compared to first quarter of last year. This increase is primarily the result of higher personnel costs, compensation in healthcare costs combined with an increase in legal costs in 2010 compared to 2009. As in prior quarters, the continuing defense costs for the Engle Progeny Cases underway in Florida impacted this quarter and will be with us for quite some time. First quarter operating income increased roughly 30% to $382 million or 41.4% of sales excluding excise taxes, from $294 million or 38.3% of net sales excluding excise taxes in last year's first quarter. Operating income per unit shipped increased approximately 16% compared with last year's first quarter, a reflection of the higher unit volume this year.
Interest expense totaled $10 million for the first quarter of this year and reflects interest expense on our $750 million notes issue, net of the effect of the interest rate swap that we entered in the third quarter of last year. Our effective income tax rate for the first quarter of 2010 was 37.8%, slightly more than the 37.7% that we saw in 2009. 
As a result of the passage of the much-publicized health care bill, which included a repeal of the tax benefits related to the Medicare Part D subsidies, income tax expense includes a one-time charge of $2 million. This increase was partially offset by an increase in the manufactures deduction in 2010 compared to 2009. We estimate that the effective income tax rate for the year will approximate 37.4%.
Net income for the first quarter of 2010 was $232 million or $1.50 per share, compared to $184 million or $1.09 per share in the first quarter of 2009. The $0.41 improvement in EPS in 2010 includes the positive impact of a lower average share count, which amounts to about $0.12 a share. Another word of caution, as we've said, comparisons of volumes in the first two quarters of 2010 to last year are tricky and can lead to erroneous conclusions both about volume and about earnings trends.
In February, we announced the $250 million share repurchase program and during the quarter, we repurchased 1.1 million shares of our stock in open market transactions at average price of $75.60 per share. As of March 31, 2010, we had approximately $136 million remaining for repurchases under that program, which is still underway. I know many of you will want to know whether we intend to use the proceeds of the recently completed bond offering to further increase our share repurchase activity, but as of this date visit, I cannot comment on what, when or how much the board may authorize the company to repurchase in the future. With that, I'd like to open the line for questions. Alicia?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Nik Modi from UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Nik Modi from UBS.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Marty, can you just comment on the share again -- I mean there was significant this quarter. Just wondering aside from wonderful management, what exactly is driving this magnitude of share gains? Was there something going on in the competitive landscape?
componenttext: Marty, can you just comment on the share again -- I mean there was significant this quarter. Just wondering aside from wonderful management, what exactly is driving this magnitude of share gains? Was there something going on in the competitive landscape?  And then the other question is can you give us a sense on how much potential inventory you believe is kind of excess in the channel so we can better understand kind of what the trend could look like in the second quarter?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the share gains, well, it is very good management. And I might add, our share gains are solely due to organic growth. They're not a by-product of line extending and filling pipelines with the new versions of Newport. I think it's a continuatio
componenttext: In terms of the share gains, well, it is very good management. And I might add, our share gains are solely due to organic growth. They're not a by-product of line extending and filling pipelines with the new versions of Newport. I think it's a continuation of our strategy, as we said in our release and I think I said in my own comments, the execution of our strategy, which is to be very targeted with respect to where we support the Newport brand and market by market and conceivably, certain decisions made by our competitors that are helping us as opposed to helping themselves. But beyond that, nothing's changed for us. We've consistently executed our target-marketed approach to investment spending, and by that, I mean promotion support for Newport in select markets based on their potential for profitable return of share growth. And that's -- obviously, it continues to work well for us. With respect to the excess inventory in the system, we estimate that it's about 200 million units, mostly Newport that are in the system that are likely to be flushed out, as I indicated, sometime in the second quarter. It's hard to say when. We don't know specifically what the motivation of the purchases, behind the purchases were, but if it was related to price, then somebody's holding on until there might be a price increase. But we don't know that for a fact.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And just on the Newport front, in terms of what was shipped from wholesale to retail. Would it kind of like a 3% to 4% down numbers make sense for the quarter?
componenttext: And just on the Newport front, in terms of what was shipped from wholesale to retail. Would it kind of like a 3% to 4% down numbers make sense for the quarter?

componenttext: Yes.

componenttextpreview: No. Adjusted, we're about flat.
componenttext: No. Adjusted, we're about flat.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Marty, I want to understand about the extra units that built up during the quarter. Does this quarter's income statement reflect the promotional costs that will ultimately be associated with the retail sell-through of that product?
componenttext: Marty, I want to understand about the extra units that built up during the quarter. Does this quarter's income statement reflect the promotional costs that will ultimately be associated with the retail sell-through of that product?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: No. Let me point out something else, David. This buildup didn't just begin in the first quarter of this year. So it was -- it began in the fourth quarter of last year and carried through. So it's not a -- it wasn't a sudden effect or impact, and so these
componenttext: No. Let me point out something else, David. This buildup didn't just begin in the first quarter of this year. So it was -- it began in the fourth quarter of last year and carried through. So it's not a -- it wasn't a sudden effect or impact, and so these units do not carry any costs beyond what we've got by selling the units.

componenttext: So to be clear, let's imagine if some of it comes out next quarter, you'll both not have those shipments, but also you'll have promotional expense associated with the sell-through of that volume.

componenttext: I'm not sure I understand. What do you mean by promotional [ph]?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: In other words, with these units that sold -- as the unit do build up in the inventory, are they particularly profitable volume, because you don't have the associated promotional spending costs?
componenttext: In other words, with these units that sold -- as the unit do build up in the inventory, are they particularly profitable volume, because you don't have the associated promotional spending costs?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. They're pure profit but we don't lose anything. The promotional costs associated with retail promotion spending only is effective when the unit is in the store and moves out. It has nothing to do, there's no relationship, no correlation to promotiona
componenttext: Yes. They're pure profit but we don't lose anything. The promotional costs associated with retail promotion spending only is effective when the unit is in the store and moves out. It has nothing to do, there's no relationship, no correlation to promotional expense at all.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I realize it's early days in the process, but as it relates to the FDA and the menthol study, is there anything that's occurred so far that causes you to alter in any way your assessment of the likely ultimate outcome of the process?
componenttext: I realize it's early days in the process, but as it relates to the FDA and the menthol study, is there anything that's occurred so far that causes you to alter in any way your assessment of the likely ultimate outcome of the process?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: No, the initial meetings in our minds were not surprising in any real sense. We certainly expected the thrust of the meetings to be as they were. So nothing's really materially changed in our minds, even though obviously there was a burst of interest and
componenttext: No, the initial meetings in our minds were not surprising in any real sense. We certainly expected the thrust of the meetings to be as they were. So nothing's really materially changed in our minds, even though obviously there was a burst of interest and noise surrounding the meetings but nothing's changed as far as we're concerned. The issue remains the same. It doesn't make any difference what any posturing might take place during the course of these meetings. And any speculation that might grow out of that posturing, the reality is as we've said repeatedly, the weight of the evidence from an demonological standpoint and other aspects of studies that have been conducted would not reflect that menthol is any different in terms of its effect on the public health than non-menthol cigarettes are. That isn't changed... We also believe that the FDA will be obligated to review the contraband dimension, associated with potential -- if in fact there was any thought about banning menthol cigarettes, what that might imply. None of that's changed.  So we have not altered our view either.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: As it relates to Maverick, is that brand benefiting from increases in its distribution? Or is the growth simply selling more within the existing store footprint?
componenttext: As it relates to Maverick, is that brand benefiting from increases in its distribution? Or is the growth simply selling more within the existing store footprint?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say at this point, it's mostly benefiting from organic growth where it is. Obviously, it continues to gain distribution but most of the gains from distribution occurred probably about a year ago. Right now, we're just -- it's pure it's incremental
componenttext: I would say at this point, it's mostly benefiting from organic growth where it is. Obviously, it continues to gain distribution but most of the gains from distribution occurred probably about a year ago. Right now, we're just -- it's pure it's incremental growth.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Lastly on the emotional [indiscernible] tobacco efforts, do you have anything as of yet in test?
componenttext: Lastly on the emotional [indiscernible] tobacco efforts, do you have anything as of yet in test?

componenttext: No, we have not. And we'll let you know when we do.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Judy Hong from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Judy Hong from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Marty, I know that there's a lot of noise in the quarter for the industry as a whole and for your perspective, but just getting a broad sense of where the industry really stands right now, obviously, it's been a year since you had the excise tax increases
componenttext: Marty, I know that there's a lot of noise in the quarter for the industry as a whole and for your perspective, but just getting a broad sense of where the industry really stands right now, obviously, it's been a year since you had the excise tax increases, it seems like the premium segment's starting to stabilize. Can you just give us your broad assessment of where you think the industry is in both on the volume side and just in terms of the promotional environment.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the promotional I think go from the back-end to the front. The promotional environment has not changed radically. It's been pretty much consistent frankly, for the last year or so. So there's really nothing of any major consequence promotionally tha
componenttext: Well, the promotional I think go from the back-end to the front. The promotional environment has not changed radically. It's been pretty much consistent frankly, for the last year or so. So there's really nothing of any major consequence promotionally that's affecting the business. To be honest with you, Judy, it's very difficult to reach a conclusion as I think I've indicated, with respect to where the trends are, with respect to the industry itself. I think each company has its own unique set of issues. Each major company has its unique set of issues that make it difficult at this stage of the game to sort of step back and look at it and say here's kind of where it's heading. I still think that we're going to be slightly worse than the industry. We'll be slightly worse than historical trends, with respect to overall shipment decline for 2010 versus 2009, with the magic percentages, I don't know. I've said somewhere in the range of 4% to 5%. I don't know how accurate that is. It's still very difficult to surmise what is actually going to happen out there. We had some noise in the first quarter from a volume standpoint, not only because of the upward adjusted on the wholesale inventories side, but because one of our major competitors introduced a line extension and had a huge impact, unit volume wise, on the industry numbers obviously. It inflated the [indiscernible]. So it's real tough at this stage of the game to determine where it's going to come out.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: But it seems like if we sort of take a lot of the numbers that you've given us as it relates to inventory movement, there may be a few adjusted Newport kind of being flat-ish on an underlying level, where the industry in the first quarter is still negativ
componenttext: But it seems like if we sort of take a lot of the numbers that you've given us as it relates to inventory movement, there may be a few adjusted Newport kind of being flat-ish on an underlying level, where the industry in the first quarter is still negatively impacted by year-over-year pricing. It just seems like the Newport's, either the gap between Newport versus the industry is widening or maybe the industry is starting to look more normal?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know what normal is, Judy. We may have a redefinition of normal and that's my point. I don't know and I think each -- if we look at our retail numbers in the first quarter, then I would say we were growing stronger week-to-week as we've moved thro
componenttext: I don't know what normal is, Judy. We may have a redefinition of normal and that's my point. I don't know and I think each -- if we look at our retail numbers in the first quarter, then I would say we were growing stronger week-to-week as we've moved through the quarter on a comparative basis, with the first quarter of last year. But the first quarter of last year as you well know, is a very, very distorted picture. So I'm not going to comment any further. It would be purely speculation on my part and I really don't have an answer to your question. I think we're going to have to wait and see as the old cliché goes, time heals all wounds and will tell us what the trends are.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010

componenttext: There were some favorable adjustments in the first quarter when we got final assessment on both the four states and the MSA numbers when the builds finally came in,had to do with volume adjustment offset, volume adjustment. I would guess that on MSA per pack level Judy, it impacted us between 3% in 4% favorably.

componenttext: 3% to 4% on a per unit basis?

componenttext: Yes.

componenttext: Is there a LIFO charge this quarter that -- as we've seen in the past few quarters?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: That's a tough question. We've added our inventory in a LIFO method, yes, and so there will be, we estimate a LIFO charge during 2010. As you know, it's an annual calculation so all we can do is make some estimates. Yes, there will be an expected LIFO cha
componenttext: That's a tough question. We've added our inventory in a LIFO method, yes, and so there will be, we estimate a LIFO charge during 2010. As you know, it's an annual calculation so all we can do is make some estimates. Yes, there will be an expected LIFO charge during the year, but we also expect it to be substantially less than last year.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: A broad question for you Marty, relative to price gaps in the category today, if you look at them and we've seen them come down for some of the other premium brands, kind of that low 30% range, is that the right level? As we've seen the consumer pick up f
componenttext: A broad question for you Marty, relative to price gaps in the category today, if you look at them and we've seen them come down for some of the other premium brands, kind of that low 30% range, is that the right level? As we've seen the consumer pick up from here, should we see that expand a bit as you or other economists attempt to kind of better balance profitability against market share growth. Do you see that as an opportunity for the premium brands throughout the year?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: The price gap has become almost an aberrational factor in a way. Keep in mind, I know you're aware of this, when the S&T increase took place the price gaps automatically narrowed between high and low just because the basis of low-priced brands and high-pr
componenttext: The price gap has become almost an aberrational factor in a way. Keep in mind, I know you're aware of this, when the S&T increase took place the price gaps automatically narrowed between high and low just because the basis of low-priced brands and high-priced brands were different and with a mathematical effect or average medical. So then with state excise taxes going up and they have, and will continue to, it affects the GAAP. So to some extent, we're captives other than anyone taking a very specific action to get a lower rate in prices. So it's a hard one to answer. I don't know. I think it's what it is and we don't manage to price gaps per se, not between high and low. We manage our pricing to ensure that we're competitive, but we don't really look at price gaps. We look at it as a piece of information.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess for your brand, for the Newport Brand, you're not managing to that but in the sense, the competition in your category remains high so arguably that, however you look at it, but the price gap couldn't really expand any in the short run given ho
componenttext: And I guess for your brand, for the Newport Brand, you're not managing to that but in the sense, the competition in your category remains high so arguably that, however you look at it, but the price gap couldn't really expand any in the short run given how competitive the activity is in the category, is that the right way to say if?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Are you saying the price gaps could expand?
componenttext: Are you saying the price gaps could expand?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm saying could not based on your view of the competitive conditions in your category, they remain high, right?
componenttext: I'm saying could not based on your view of the competitive conditions in your category, they remain high, right?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's a hard question to answer. I don't know whether they -- if you're saying 30% is low and we can go higher, I don't think that's the issue per se. And I really can't answer for what anyone else would do.
componenttext: Yes. It's a hard question to answer. I don't know whether they -- if you're saying 30% is low and we can go higher, I don't think that's the issue per se. And I really can't answer for what anyone else would do.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from Andrew Kieley from Deutsche Bank.

componenttext: Let me clarify something. Newport is in national distribution. Newport is in probably at least 200,000 to 300,000 outlets, maybe more, maybe 500,000. Whatever number of stores out there that sell cigarettes, Newport is pretty well represented. So Newport is nationally distributed. When we make distinctions about Newport's business development, on a geographic basis, from a development standpoint, and by that, I mean in terms of its market share achieved, it varies by geography. And yet the Northeast and the Southeast tend to have above average sales or of market share than Newport then does the West. But we do sell cigarettes in the West. We're not non-existent in any of those locations. Maverick again is in national distribution. It's always been in national distribution and when we've added distribution, we added more packings or SKUs as the brand has grown, but both Newport and Maverick, I can't emphasize enough, is in national distribution.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the second quarter 2010 Lorillard Inc. earnings conference call. (Operator instructions.) I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Bob Bannon. Please proceed.
componenttext: Good day ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the second quarter 2010 Lorillard Inc. earnings conference call. (Operator instructions.) I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Bob Bannon. Please proceed.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you Madge and good morning everyone. I’m Bob Bannon Lorillard’s director of Investor Relations and joining me on today’s call is Marty Orlowsky, Lorillard’s Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer and David Taylor, its Chief Financia
componenttext:
Thank you Madge and good morning everyone. I’m Bob Bannon Lorillard’s director of Investor Relations and joining me on today’s call is Marty Orlowsky, Lorillard’s Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer and David Taylor, its Chief Financial Officer.
By now you should have received a copy of our second quarter 2010 earnings release. It can be found on the company’s website, Lorillard.com, under News Releases. But, before we begin I would like to remind you that some of the comments on today’s call and some of the responses to your questions may contain forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to the risks and uncertainties as described in the company’s earnings release and in other filings with the SEC.
I would now like to turn the call over to Marty Orlowsky.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Bob. Good morning everyone. We’re pleased with the company’s performance for both the second quarter and the first six months of 2010. Lorillard and the Newport brand achieved record wholesale and retail shipment market share, and the company
componenttext:
Thanks Bob. Good morning everyone. We’re pleased with the company’s performance for both the second quarter and the first six months of 2010. Lorillard and the Newport brand achieved record wholesale and retail shipment market share, and the company’s domestic wholesale unit volume performance outperformed the industry when comparing 2010 with 2009 for the second quarter and the first 6 months of the year. 
As most of you are aware, comparing performance trends for the second quarter of 2010 and 2009 is difficult on face value and can be misleading due to distortions in wholesale and retail trade inventory purchase behavior, which resulted from the effect of the federal excise tax increase that occurred on April 1 last year. As such, a clearer picture of market performance is reflected in the first six month comparison each year, which will tend to wash out the anomalies that occurred in 2009. 
Total Lorillard domestic wholesale shipment unit volume increased 5.3% in the first half of 2010 versus 2009, compared with an industry decline of 4.9% for the same period. Newport was up 2.5% for the same six months of comparison. Wholesale shipment domestic market share for Lorillard increased by 1.10 points for the first six months of 2010, resulting in a total share of 12.16% and Newport shipment share of the domestic market for the first half of 2010 was 10.44%, an increase of 0.75 points over the first half of 2009.
At the retail level, based on our data, Newport achieved a 10.93% share in the first six months of this year, an increase of 0.66 points over the same period in 2009. (Inaudible) grew 0.44 points for the same period with comparison, achieving a 1.44 retail share of market. 
Lorillard’s performance for the first six months of 2010 reflects a continuation of the success of our core business strategy of balancing Newport’s market share performance and profitability. 
And now I’d like to turn it over to David Taylor for a recap of our financial performance.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Marty, and good morning everyone. I’ll briefly review the results and then we’ll open the line for questions. Net sales for the second quarter of 2010 were $1.52 billion, compared to $1.519 billion in the second quarter of 2009. Roughly flat
componenttext:
Thanks Marty, and good morning everyone. I’ll briefly review the results and then we’ll open the line for questions. 
Net sales for the second quarter of 2010 were $1.52 billion, compared to $1.519 billion in the second quarter of 2009. Roughly flat with last year’s second quarter. 
In last quarter’s call, we pointed out that the disruptions in shipment patterns caused by last year’s federal excise tax increase make quarter to quarter comparisons for 2009 tricky, and cautioned that a better comparison would be the first six months of 2010. When we look at the first six months, our net sales, excluding excise taxes, increased 8.8% to $1.96 billion from $1.8 billion last year. 
Total wholesale shipments declined by just under 1% for the second quarter, but increased 4.9% for the six month period. Higher net average selling prices for the second quarter essentially offset the effects of the lower volume mix and higher sales promotion costs accounted for as a reduction of sales. When these higher average selling prices are compounded by an increase in volume, such as we saw for the six-month period, the result is the almost 9% increase in net sales before excise taxes. 
Gross profit in the second quarter of 2010 declined by $10 million to $542 million, or 52.2% of sales excluding excise taxes, from $552 million or 53.4% of sales excluding excise taxes in the second quarter of 2009. 
Cost of sales in the second quarter of 2010 reflect increases for certain raw materials costs such as tobacco and wrapping costs and the new FDA fees when compared to last year’s second quarter, the same sorts of dynamics we saw in the first quarter. Amounts due under the state settlement agreements increased $4 million compared to last year’s second quarter as a result of the inflation factors in those agreements, which was partially offset by volume and market share adjustments.
Selling, general, and administrative costs remained roughly flat, increasing $1 million to $97 million in the second quarter of 2010 from last year’s $96 million. 
Second quarter operating income decreased roughly 2.4% to $445 million, or 2.9% of sales excluding excise taxes, from $456 million, or 44.1% of net sales excluding excise taxes in last year’s second quarter.
When the first six months of 2010 are compared to the same period last year, you see an increase in operating income of over 10% to $827 million from $751 million last year. Operating income per unit shipped for the six-month period increased approximately 5% compared to the first half of last year.
Interest expense totaled $28 million in the second quarter of 2010 and reflects interest expense on our senior notes net of the effect of the interest rate swap which lowered our interest expense by $6 million in the second quarter.
Our effective income tax rate in the second quarter was 37.1%, the same as last year’s quarter, and we currently estimate that the effective tax rate for the full year will approximate 37.2%.
Net income for the second quarter of 2010 was $263 million or $1.73 per share compared to $286 million or $1.71 per share in the second quarter of 2009. 
Earnings per share for the first six months of 2010 was $3.22 per diluted share compared to $2.80 per diluted share for the first six months of last year. The $0.42 improvement in EPS in 2010 includes the positive impact of the lower average share count, which amounted to about $0.28 per share.
As we have said, comparisons of volumes in the first two quarters of 2010 to last year can be confusing. So we think investors and others should look at the first half of 2010 and compare it to last year. When those comparisons are made, with most of the noise surrounding last year’s excise tax increase equalized, the picture is impressive: a unit volume increase of almost 5%, a sales increase of almost 9%, an operating income increase of 10%, and an EPS increase of 15%. A successful first half by almost any measure. 
In February, we announced a $250 million share repurchase program, which was completed during the quarter after having purchased 3.3 million shares at an average price of $76.29 under that program.
I know that many of you will want to know whether we intend to use the proceeds of our recently completed bond offering to further increase our share repurchase activity, but as of this date I cannot comment on what, when, or how much the board may authorize the company to repurchase in the future.
With that, I’d like to open the line for questions. Madge, could you do that for us?

componenttextpreview: It was about a $2 million unit carryover from the first quarter into the second quarter and that pretty much got washed out through the second quarter. And then again there was a slight uptick in inventory build by some wholesalers in anticipation, and ma
componenttext: It was about a $2 million unit carryover from the first quarter into the second quarter and that pretty much got washed out through the second quarter. And then again there was a slight uptick in inventory build by some wholesalers in anticipation, and maybe even the retailers, in anticipation of the New York State excise tax increase that took effect July 1. But I don’t think that was a material number to deal with, so I’m going to say for all practical purposes all of that stuff has been basically washed through the system.

componenttext: Just to clarify, Marty, in the third quarter of last year, though, you had another pretty significant destocking on the Newport volume, so when we think about the third quarter shipment trends, doesn’t that really give you a very favorable comparison, just in terms of year-over-year inventory movement comparisons?

componenttext: Well frankly, we haven’t really witnessed any significant shifts in terms of the competitive framework so far through the year. I would not necessarily, I can’t anticipate at this stage of the game whether there’s going to be any radical or significant change occurring. So assuming all things remain as they’ve pretty much been, the Newport brand should continue to perform competitively, as it has.

componenttext: That’s correct. We have not been. We are not, obviously, involved in the vast majority of the cases. I think the count was . . . We’re obviously not represented in the majority of the cases, and to date, as you’ve said, we have not been involved in a trial. Obviously that can happen at any point in time going into the future, but in the overall mix of it, we’re a much lesser factor with respect to the totality of the cases that are involved in this whole business.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then one last thing, Marty, on the FDA. Am I correct that the FDA is not under . . . once the scientific advisory panel comes up with a recommendation, whatever that recommendation is, the FDA is not under any mandated timeframe to take action i
componenttext: Okay, and then one last thing, Marty, on the FDA. Am I correct that the FDA is not under . . . once the scientific advisory panel comes up with a recommendation, whatever that recommendation is, the FDA is not under any mandated timeframe to take action if any in response to that recommendation. Is that correct?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-26-2010
componenttextpreview: That is correct. The only one under the time clock is the committee itself, but the FDA certainly is not, just as the FDA is not obliged necessarily to follow the recommendation itself. They have the option as you well know to consider the input from the
componenttext: That is correct. The only one under the time clock is the committee itself, but the FDA certainly is not, just as the FDA is not obliged necessarily to follow the recommendation itself. They have the option as you well know to consider the input from the committee and consider other aspects of the issue, so in either case the FDA is not under the clock.

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Marty, I know you said the impact on second-quarter shipments due to the New York State tax increase wasn’t material. Is there a round number you could put on that, and then does that create a challenge for your third quarter shipments, and are you seei
componenttext: Marty, I know you said the impact on second-quarter shipments due to the New York State tax increase wasn’t material. Is there a round number you could put on that, and then does that create a challenge for your third quarter shipments, and are you seeing any early impact on the consumer takeaway in New York as a result?

headline: Lorillard, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-26-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I can’t quantify it. I don’t really know what it is. As I said, it wasn’t very significant, and I don’t think that the early buying in the second quarter for the third quarter is going to have any sort of real material impact on third-quarter
componenttext:
No, I can’t quantify it. I don’t really know what it is. As I said, it wasn’t very significant, and I don’t think that the early buying in the second quarter for the third quarter is going to have any sort of real material impact on third-quarter numbers. 
And we have not seen, yet, any effects of consumer takeaway based on the pricing that’s now in effect in New York City and New York State. So, right now we perform pretty well in the past following excise tax increases in New York State, some of which have been rather substantial in nature. 
Again, that’s not a guarantee that the future will perform the same way, but clearly, and it’s not an encouraging situation to be in with the kinds of increases that took place in New York, but nonetheless, we have to view it as we do excise tax increases in any state. There tends to be an adjustment on the part of consumers over time. 
We may, may, and I emphasize that, see some negative impact in the short term at some point following this excise tax increase, but we’re reasonably confident that over time we will perform reasonably well. Our market share in New York State has actually been growing rather substantially over the past couple of years, even in light of what took place following all of those tax increases. 
So we’re very cautious about what the situation is there and feel reasonably confident that it will not have a major, major impact on us.
